description: From Middle English in kenebowe, in kene bowe (“in a keen bow”, i.e. “in a sharp bend or angle”), from in (“in”) + keen, kene (“brave, keen, sharp”) + bowe (“bow, bend”). Alternately, possibly from Old Norse kengr (“bent”) + bogi (“a bow”), compare Icelandic kengboginn (“bow-bent”).

entries.meaning: With a crook or bend; with the hand on the hip and elbow turned outward.
examples: Men preferred one pose above all others, namely, the elbow akimbo.

entries.meaning: Into, in, or of the position where the arms are akimbo.
Of weapons, especially firearms: one held in each hand.
examples: Although it was a little impractical, Elmer held his revolvers akimbo because to him it looked cool.
